For a quantum sensing protocol that uses projective measurements on a multi-qubit sensor array to infer the trajectory of an incident particle, we establish that entanglement can dramatically reduce the particle-qubit interaction strength θ required for perfect trajectory discrimination

Within an interval of θabove this reduced threshold, any unentangled sensor requires Θ(log(1 /ϵ)) repetitions of the protocol to estimate a previously unknown particle trajectory with ϵerror probability, whereas an entangled sensor can succeed with zero error in a single shot

We solve this problem and show for some threshold θminthat for all θ∈[θmin, π), there exist entangled sensor states that perfectly discriminate trajectories in a single shot while any unentangled sensor must instead fail with nonzero probability

In biology and chemistry, positron emission tomography localizes tumors along a line traversed by emitted gamma photons [4], and mass spectrometers determine molar masses by filtering charged molecular fragments according to their trajectories [5]
